facts: Your muscles get stronger during rest because tiny exercise-caused tears repair and rebuild tougher than before.
A good warm-up raises your body temperature and increases blood flow, which can help you move better and lower injury risk.
Drinking water helps your body cool itself through sweat and supports your heart as it pumps blood during exercise.
Doing strength exercises like squats or push-ups can build muscle and also help make bones stronger over time.
You can improve heart health with activities like brisk walking, biking, or swimming because they keep your heart rate up for longer periods.
Flexibility work such as stretching can help joints move through a wider range of motion and may reduce stiffness.
Sleep is a key part of fitness because it helps your brain and body recover, including balancing hormones that affect energy and growth.
